column1: Which is the MOST important of the following concepts?
column2: Love
column4: Honor
column6: Fairness

column1: Which is the LEAST important of the following concepts?
column2: Love
column4: Honor
column6: Fairness

column1: Society works best when there is a detailed justice system.
column2: I agree
column4: I disagree
column6: depends on the situation.

column1: Friendship and loyalty are far more important than the law
column2: Yes, meaningful friendships outlast any law.
column4: No, the law must come before my personal feelings, even if they are close relations.
column6: Well of course!, my friends and I don't even know the law, he he he.

column1: Doing the right thing is its own reward
column2: Always, or else how would one choose what to do?
column4: That all depends on what you mean by the term 'right'.
column6: Without a reward, there is no point in doing anything!

column1: When the going gets tough, the tough eliminate the competition
column2: No, that wouldn't be respectable
column4: Well, if it balances the playing field, I suppose so.
column6: Of course, all is fair in. . .  well, just about everything.

column1: Crime never pays
column2: True, true.
column4: It might in the short run, but everything comes back around in the end.
column6: Crime may not pay the victim, but I sure get rich!

column1: Being spontaneous is far better than always planning things out
column2: No, this only leads to confusion and inefficiency.
column4: There is a time for everything
column6: Spontanaity is the spice of life!

column1: Where would you MOST like to live?
column2: The big city, full of people, shops, bars, and all that urban goodness.  A place where you can be a part of something greater than yourself.
column4: Mountain Halls: deep, cavernous, and majestic, no rules but survival.
column6: A Small Village, with a few people and a handful of busniesses, where you can have some control.
column8: A monastery or temple, where you can provide for others, away from the politics of city life.

column1: Somebody plays a joke on you; what's your first reaction?
column2: Laugh. Fun is fun, after all.
column4: Ignore them. Pranks are beneath me.
column6: Get them back, but in a nice way.
column8: Hurt, injure, or otherwise maim the bastard.

column1: What type of people would you MOST like to associate with?
column2: Lawyers and Politicians
column4: Judges and Merchants
column6: Minions and Servants
column10: Me, Myself, and I (none of the above)

column1: While walking past a dark alley, you notice two thugs beating up a merchant, obviously intent on robbery. What do you do?
column2: Kill them all and loot the bodies.
column4: Call the watch and let them handle it.
column6: Ignore them, the merchant might have deserved it.
column8: Try to fight them off, getting between the thugs and the merchant

column1: By adventuring, I am primarily. . .
column2: . . .just doing my part to put things right.
column4: . . .rescuing the weak and helping the helpless.
column6: . . .enjoying the thrill of the dangers faced.
column8: . . .acquiring wealth and power through this experience.

column1: Were I not fit for an adventuring class, I would most likely be. . .
column2: a man-at-arms in a nearby castle.
column4: a bandit raiding the countryside.
column6: an herbalist treating the sick.
column8: a hermit living alone in the wilderness.

column1: My hero is. . .
column2: Robin Hood.
column4: King Arthur.
column6: Attilla the Hun.
column10: None of the above suit my taste, they are all to extreme for me.

column1: I see myself more as. . .
column2: . . .an honerable soldier.
column4: . . .a beloved hero.
column6: . . .a powerful adventurer.

column1: You find hidden treasure of several million gold coins. What do you do with them?
column2: Shopping spree!
column4: Donate them to a temple.
column6: Ask around about who's it might be, so you can spend it without arousing suspicion.
column8: Tell the guards in hope of a reward
column12: Invest in real estate or financial institutions.

column1: At the end of a successful venture,
column2: I kill everyone and take all the loot.
column4: the party leaders divide the loot evenly and begin planning the next grand adventure.
column6: I would look for ways to help others with my share of the rewards.
column8: we part company, and I go enjoy a bit of peace my own way.

column1: Choose a statement that best fits your style.
column2: Careful planning is the surest way to assure success.
column4: Opportunities come to those flexible enough to grasp them.
column6: One should always be ready to help others.

column1: Choose the statement about which you feel strongly.
column2: If people were truly free, crime would disappear.
column4: Prosperity for all is only possible where crime is controlled.
column6: Government makes it possible for the best people to rise to the top.
column8: The function of the police is to oppress those who are just trying to survive.
column10: Every government has its ups and downs and needs to be balanced with occasional opposition to remain so.

column1: I believe that. . .
column2: . . .no creature can ever claim ownership of any other creature.
column4: . . .stronger creatures use slavery to take advantage of the weak.
column6: . . .slavery is a reasonable solution to certain economic problems.
column8: . . .some people deserve to be served by others.

column1: Concerning government, I feel that. . .
column2: . . .the government which governs least governs best.
column4: . . .the one who always does good need not fear the law.
column6: . . .without law, society would collapse.
column8: . . .any situation can be made to work to one's own advantage.

column1: Concerning duty, I feel that. . .
column2: . . .each of us has a duty to all of us.
column4: . . .each of us has a duty to our country and its government.
column6: . . .each of us has a duty to himself.
column8: . . .there is no duty common to all.
